Award.AwardTitle: A Course in Plant Breeding for Drought Tolerance - June 14-23, 2010 at Colorado State University (CO)
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: John K McKay, Colorado State University
co-PI: Patrick F Byrne, Colorado State University

A two week course "Plant Breeding for Drought Tolerance" will be held on June 14-23, 2010 at Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado. The goal of the short-course is to enhance education in plant breeding for drought tolerance by providing training opportunities to next generation plant breeders, plant physiologists, geneticists, and agronomists, and to increase the diversity of representation within these disciplines. The workshop involves a combination of hands-on activities, lectures, field exercises, and laboratory, and a two-day symposium on plant breeding, physiology and genomics of drought adaptation. The funding provided by NSF will broaden participation by defraying the costs of tuitions and/or travel for graduate students and junior scientists including women and individuals from underrepresented groups from the scientific communities of the US and developing countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Drought stress is ubiquitous, is an important selective agent in the evolution of plant growth, development and physiology, and is a major limiting factor to crop productivity. Moisture deficits loom as one of the greatest challenges to future crop production, both in developed and developing countries. Crops chronically attain only about 50% of their potential yield due to the effects of environmental stress, with drought stress the most important cause. Although changes in tillage and irrigation practices can improve production by conserving water, enhancing the genetic tolerance of crops to drought stress is also considered an essential strategy for addressing moisture deficits. Drought avoidance increasingly will be a necessary characteristic for irrigated as well as dry land crop cultivars. Plant Breeding for drought tolerance will increasingly rely on mechanistic understanding of the genetic and genomic basis of variation in how water availability influences plant growth and yield. In June 2010, Drs. McKay and Byrn organized and ran the first and only domestic Plant Breeding for Drought Tolerance short course, in order to advance knowledge and encourage excitement in the next generation of plant breeders, plant physiologists, geneticists, and agronomists. 

 

 For the first iteration of the course, we received 85 completed applications. From those, we selected 30 students based upon their personal statement of how the course fits into their research and training plans. Of these 30, all were graduate students or researchers. We are very excited that we had a lot of interest, a strong pool of applicants to select from and a culturally diverse group of researchers working at Universities, International Agricultural Research Centers (CGIAR) and industry. The course, which took place in June 2010 was a great success by promoting knowledge and diversity in the plant breeding and genetics community by advancing intellectual exchange in this new generation of scientists. This course will be repeated again in June 2012, and in future years if funding continues.
